Articles: {"abstract": "The Altria Group will formally announce its plan to spin off its Kraft Foods unit Wednesday, according to The Financial Times, marking the end of a 20-year era marked by tobacco litigation. Altria, which acquired Kraft in 1988 for $13.1 billion cash, will release details of what will be one of the largest tax-free corporate spin-offs on the day it reports fourth-quarter earnings, The newspaper said. It added that Altria is likely to spin its 88.6 percent stake in Kraft by giving its shareholders 1.46 billion Kraft shares.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2007/01/29/altria-expected-to-announce-kraft-spin-off-this-week/", "snippet": "", "lead_paragraph": "The Altria Group will formally announce its plan to spin off its Kraft Foods unit Wednesday, according to The Financial Times, marking the end of a 20-year era marked by tobacco litigation. {"abstract": "The Altria Group, the cigarette maker, will close a North Carolina factory and increase European production to save $335 million a year by 2011. The shutdown of the plant in Cabarrus County will result in a one-time charge of $325 million in the second quarter, Altria said. The company, which is based in New York, may be preparing to spin off its international unit, analysts and investors said. Factories in Europe will take over production of Marlboros and other cigarettes bound for Japan and the Middle East, which are currently being made in North Carolina. All of Altria\u2019s United States output will be shifted to Richmond, Va. Closing the North Carolina facility, which employs 2,500, will cost about 10 cents a share in the second quarter, Altria said. {"abstract": "The National Beef Packing Company, the fourth-largest United States beef processor, said that its sale to a Brazilian beef producer, JBS, had been dropped.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/21/business/21bizbriefs-BUYOUTOFMEAT_BRF.html", "snippet": "The National Beef Packing Company, the fourth-largest United States beef processor, said that its sale to a Brazilian beef producer, JBS, had been dropped.", "lead_paragraph": "A beef industry buyout that regulators were trying to block on antitrust grounds has been called off. The National Beef Packing Company, the fourth-largest United States beef processor, said that its sale to a Brazilian beef producer, JBS, had been dropped. JBS said last March that it would acquire National Beef, based in Kansas City, Mo., in a $560 million stock-and-cash transaction. In October, the Justice Department filed a lawsuit to block the deal, saying it could push up costs for consumers and drive down prices paid to ranchers and feedlots.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Buyout of Meatpacker Is Dropped", "kicker": "Business Briefing | Company News", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Buyout Of Meatpacker Is Dropped", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "National Beef Packing", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "ANTITRUST ACTIONS AND LAWS", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Meat", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2009-02-21T04:44:50+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By ASSOCIATED PRESS", "person": [], "organization": "ASSOCIATED PRESS"}, "type_of_material": "Brief", "_id": "nyt://article/985ab308-5907-5df8-b0eb-48200475cde1", "word_count": 93, "uri": "nyt://article/985ab308-5907-5df8-b0eb-48200475cde1"}

{"abstract": "Banks in Missouri and Nevada were seized by regulators, bringing the total of federally insured failed banks to 25.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/18/business/economy/18bizbriefs-REGULATORSCL_BRF.html", "snippet": "Banks in Missouri and Nevada were seized by regulators, bringing the total of federally insured failed banks to 25.", "lead_paragraph": "Banks in Missouri and Nevada were seized by regulators, bringing the total of federally insured failed banks to 25. The total equals the number of banks shuttered in all of last year, as the recession drives up unemployment and home foreclosures. American Sterling Bank of Sugar Creek, Mo., and the Great Basin Bank of Nevada in Elko were closed. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was named receiver.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Regulators Close 2 Banks, Bringing Total to 25 in \u201909", "kicker": "Business Briefing | Company News", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Regulators Close 2 Banks, Bringing Total To 25 In \u201909", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Federal Deposit Insurance Corp", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Banks and Banking", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Recession and Depression", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2009-04-18T03:25:21+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Economy", "byline": {"original": "By Bloomberg News", "person": [{"firstname": "Bloomberg", "middlename": null, "lastname": "News", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Brief", "_id": "nyt://article/928f02e2-bd0b-56c1-82bc-c91d3489f25c", "word_count": 176, "uri": "nyt://article/928f02e2-bd0b-56c1-82bc-c91d3489f25c"}

{"abstract": "I\u2019d seen this before: These people knew how to build a product, but they did not know how to build a company.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/01/06/starting-over-at-a-lexington-manufacturing-plant/", "snippet": "I\u2019d seen this before: These people knew how to build a product, but they did not know how to build a company.", "lead_paragraph": "It was almost 30 years ago that I led a management buyout of what was then a failing International Harvester factory in Springfield, Mo. As it is now, the economy then was in the tank and capital was next to impossible to come by. I was convinced that our only hope was to open the books and teach every employee how to think like an owner. As I explained in my first post, things have worked out pretty well for the company we created, SRC Holdings. ", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Starting Over at a Lexington Manufacturing Plant", "kicker": "You're the Boss", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2010-01-06T15:13:10+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Entrepreneurship", "byline": {"original": "By Jack Stack", "person": [{"firstname": "Jack", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Stack", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "", "_id": "nyt://article/565bb5ff-440c-506f-85e8-17fc65aa7648", "word_count": 629, "uri": "nyt://article/565bb5ff-440c-506f-85e8-17fc65aa7648"}

{"abstract": "The company once called Philip Morris is hoping the F.D.A. will go easier on Marlboro Snus, a spit-free smokeless pouch, than on Marlboro cigarettes.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/31/business/31altria.html", "snippet": "The company once called Philip Morris is hoping the F.D.A. will go easier on Marlboro Snus, a spit-free smokeless pouch, than on Marlboro cigarettes.", "lead_paragraph": "FOR years, Altria, home to Philip Morris and its popular Marlboro cigarette brand, was a corporate pariah blamed for the deaths of millions of people and sued for hundreds of billions of dollars by attorneys general in every state. After eventually acknowledging, like others in its industry, that cigarette smoking was, indeed, addictive and caused disease, Altria went a step further. It broke from the Big Tobacco pack and began supporting legislation that would ultimately put the company under the regulatory thumb of the Food and Drug Administration.", "print_section": "BU", {"abstract": "When the annual sales-and-marketing plan is presented at this company, the associates are asked to vote on their confidence level. Last June, the results weren\u2019t so good.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/04/13/how-we-try-to-get-buy-in-part-1/", "snippet": "When the annual sales-and-marketing plan is presented at this company, the associates are asked to vote on their confidence level. Last June, the results weren\u2019t so good.", "lead_paragraph": "On the morning of June 22, 2009, all 78 associates of SRC Power Systems, which makes custom-engineered power units and is based in Springfield, Mo., filed onto the shop floor to hear an hour-long presentation about the company\u2019s latest sales-and-marketing plan. People grabbed folding chairs where available while others sat on wire containers or floor baskets near their tools and workstations. There was a dark mood in the air. One guy leaned up against an engine crate, his arms folded across his chest and his jaw set. It was as if he already didn\u2019t like what he was about to hear.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "How We Try to Get Buy-In, Part 1", "kicker": "You're the Boss", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2010-04-13T13:00:45+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Entrepreneurship", "byline": {"original": "By Jack Stack", "person": [{"firstname": "Jack", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Stack", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "", "_id": "nyt://article/6e4e0f23-eb06-5069-86eb-6aafe8f89404", "word_count": 814, "uri": "nyt://article/6e4e0f23-eb06-5069-86eb-6aafe8f89404"}

{"abstract": "H&R Block told investors to ignore speculation that it faced a surge in costs tied to its defunct mortgage business.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/04/business/04bizbriefs-HRBLOCKDISMI_BRF.html", "snippet": "H&R Block told investors to ignore speculation that it faced a surge in costs tied to its defunct mortgage business.", "lead_paragraph": "H&R Block told investors to ignore speculation that it faced a surge in costs tied to its defunct mortgage business. Concern about potential losses tied to buybacks of home loans \u201cis not based on fact,\u201d and reserves to protect the company against claims are adequate, the chief executive, Alan M. Bennett, said Thursday during a conference call about fiscal first-quarter earnings. The call included repeated queries about claims, which have totaled more than $680 million. H&R Block originated mortgages through January 2008, and some were sold to become part of mortgage-backed securities. The company\u2019s mortgage buyback liability \u201cremains within our reserved expectations, and we continue to view related reserves as adequate,\u201d the chief financial officer, Jeffrey T. Brown, said. H&R Block reported a loss from continuing operations of $127.6 million, or 40 cents a share, for the three months ending July 10, compared with $130.6 million, or 39 cents, in the same period last year. Its net loss narrowed to $130.7 million from $133.6 million. Shares of H&R Block, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., rose 73 cents, or 6 percent, to $13.30. ", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "H&R Block Dismisses Concerns About Mortgages", "kicker": "Business Briefing | Finance", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "H&R Block Dismisses Concerns About Mortgages", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "H&R Block Incorporated", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Mortgages", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2010-09-04T01:31:52+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Bloomberg News", "person": [{"firstname": "Bloomberg", "middlename": null, "lastname": "News", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Brief", "_id": "nyt://article/c443cc5f-ed21-5602-82a9-9c6ab0b9a3f7", "word_count": 186, "uri": "nyt://article/c443cc5f-ed21-5602-82a9-9c6ab0b9a3f7"}

{"abstract": "The nation\u2019s employers shed 533,000 jobs in November, the 11th consecutive monthly decline, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported Friday. Not since December 1974, toward the end of a severe recession, have so many jobs disappeared in a single month. The unemployment rate rose to 6.7 percent, up just two-tenths of a percentage point from October in part because it does not include all those too discouraged to look for work any longer or those working fewer hours than they would like. The number of part-time workers who want full-time work rose sharply, to 7.3 million, up 62.2 percent from November of last year.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2008/12/04/business/economy/20081205-unemployment-graphic.html", "snippet": "The nation\u2019s employers shed 533,000 jobs in November, the 11th consecutive monthly decline, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported Friday. {"abstract": "Many travelers have discovered that traveling to a strange place is much less daunting with mobile apps and social networks.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/05/business/05SOCIAL.html", "snippet": "Many travelers have discovered that traveling to a strange place is much less daunting with mobile apps and social networks.", "lead_paragraph": "WHEN Mark Rosch and his wife, Carole Levitt, were traveling to Kansas City, Mo., on a recent trip for their legal education and research business, they did not want to miss an opportunity to dine across the state line at  Oklahoma Joe\u2019s Barbecue in Kansas City, Kan. But after arriving by taxi at the award-winning restaurant, located in a former gas station in a residential area, they worried about finding a taxi to take them back to their hotel after dinner.", "print_section": "F", "print_page": "1", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "jumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2011/05/05/business/SOCIAL/SOCIAL-jumbo.jpg", "height": 1024, "width": 841, "subType": "jumbo", "crop_name": "jumbo", "legacy": {}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "thumbnail", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2011/05/05/business/SOCIAL/SOCIAL-thumbStandard.jpg", "height": 75, "width": 75, "subType": "thumbnail", "crop_name": "thumbStandard", "legacy": {"thumbnail": "images/2011/05/05/business/SOCIAL/SOCIAL-thumbStandard.jpg", "thumbnailwidth": 75, "thumbnailheight": 75}}], "headline": {"main": "Navigating With Social Media", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Navigating With Social Media", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Mobile Applications", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Social Networking (Internet)", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Business Travel", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-05-05T00:58:47+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Jennifer Preston", "person": [{"firstname": "Jennifer", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Preston", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/3d85f0e9-eaf7-5570-84c2-1f47163f79cc", "word_count": 1405, "uri": "nyt://article/3d85f0e9-eaf7-5570-84c2-1f47163f79cc"}

{"abstract": "An interactive map from the Census Bureau showing how political and economic forces have moved the center of the United States population from Kent County, Md. in 1790 to Plato, Mo., in 2010.", "web_url": "https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/05/13/the-population-shifts-westward/", "snippet": "An interactive map from the Census Bureau showing how political and economic forces have moved the center of the United States population from Kent County, Md. in 1790 to Plato, Mo., in 2010.", "lead_paragraph": "2:28 p.m. | Updated The Census Bureau has put together a neat interactive map showing the shifting center of the population, defined as \u201cthe place where an imaginary, flat, weightless and rigid map of the United States would balance perfectly if all residents were of identical weight.\u201d", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Population Shifts Westward", "kicker": "Economix", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Census", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Population", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Census Bureau", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "United States", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-05-13T16:36:50+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Economy", "byline": {"original": "By Catherine Rampell", "person": [{"firstname": "Catherine", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Rampell", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "", "_id": "nyt://article/1b2a386d-36ca-5d8e-abc8-0d850f8096d0", "word_count": 140, "uri": "nyt://article/1b2a386d-36ca-5d8e-abc8-0d850f8096d0"}

{"abstract": "Do you have a disaster plan in place for your business?", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/08/30/preparing-for-the-next-disaster-2/", "snippet": "Do you have a disaster plan in place for your business?", "lead_paragraph": "The gods must be crazy, or at the very least they seem extremely perturbed this year. Each season of 2011 has been one for the record books as far as weather events. Here in the state of Arkansas we had record cold and snowfall this winter, followed by historic flooding and tornado damage in the spring. In states throughout the south central United States, the Mississippi river went on a flooding rampage the likes of which had not been seen since the 1930s. A tornado outbreak ripped across several states, with Alabama bearing the brunt. Texas and Oklahoma are still being oppressed by relentlessly hot temperatures, and now Irene has come barreling up the eastern seaboard. Dare I ask what\u2019s next?", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Preparing for the Next Disaster", "kicker": "You're the Boss", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Customer Relations", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Disasters and Emergencies", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Insurance", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Office Buildings and Commercial Properties", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Relocation of Business", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Small Business", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Joplin (Mo)", "rank": 7, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-08-30T19:00:48+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Entrepreneurship", "byline": {"original": "By Barbara Taylor", "person": [{"firstname": "Barbara", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Taylor", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/b48e1b5d-be12-5cb2-a34e-6f7e4076cdfb", "word_count": 925, "uri": "nyt://article/b48e1b5d-be12-5cb2-a34e-6f7e4076cdfb"}

{"abstract": "Moberly, Mo., was happy to guarantee bonds for a Chinese-owned plant that promised to bring jobs to town. But when it failed, the city walked away from the bonds.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/26/business/moberly-mo-backed-a-failed-project-then-refused-to-pay.html", "snippet": "Moberly, Mo., was happy to guarantee bonds for a Chinese-owned plant that promised to bring jobs to town. But when it failed, the city walked away from the bonds.", "lead_paragraph": "Residents of Moberly, Mo., got a shock last year when they discovered that their city had guaranteed $39 million in bonds, sold by an independent authority, to help a Chinese company build a plant to make sucralose, an artificial sweetener. But it faces health concerns and the might of Big Tobacco, which wants in on the business, too.", "lead_paragraph": "Geoff Vuleta was in the crowd at a Rolling Stones concert last year when Keith Richards lit up a cigarette on stage, the arena\u2019s no-smoking policy be damned. Feeling inspired, Mr. Vuleta, a longtime smoker, reached into his pocket and pulled one out himself. People seated nearby shot him scolding glances as he inhaled. So he withdrew the cigarette from his mouth and pressed the glowing end to his cheek. {"abstract": "A loan package to a little-known company highlights a new credit boom taking shape. | Business development companies are suddenly hot, but they come with risks. | A former analyst at SAC Capital Advisors agreed to testify against his onetime boss in a bid to avoid jail time. | Men\u2019s Wearhouse turned the tables on Jos. A. Bank.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2013/11/27/morning-agenda-a-new-credit-boom/", "snippet": "A loan package to a little-known company highlights a new credit boom taking shape. | Business development companies are suddenly hot, but they come with risks. | A former analyst at SAC Capital Advisors agreed to testify against his onetime boss ...", "lead_paragraph": "A $330 million loan package to a small, little-known company from Missouri highlights how a new credit boom is taking shape, five years after the bubble, Lynnley Browning reports in DealBook. The company, Learfield Communications, of Jefferson City, Mo., owns multimedia rights to more than four dozen college sports programs and made just under $40 million last year in a common measure of earnings. It borrowed the money from Deutsche Bank and GE Capital on Oct. 9. Though the loans were rated subprime, with few of the standard protections seen in ordinary debt, investors clamored to buy pieces of the loans, one of which pays annual interest of at least 8.75 percent.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "A New Credit Boom", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2013-11-27T13:09:20+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By William Alden", "person": [{"firstname": "William", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Alden", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/387acfb5-781a-5119-b88f-62b4a538c3d5", "word_count": 2035, "uri": "nyt://article/387acfb5-781a-5119-b88f-62b4a538c3d5"}

{"abstract": "Investors are pushing up shares of Imperial Tobacco on the possibility that it could acquire brands cast off in a Reynolds-Lorillard deal, but an acquisition would be a stretch financially, and the long-term benefits may be scant.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/07/11/imperial-tobaccos-ambitions-challenge-its-balance-sheet/", "snippet": "Investors are pushing up shares of Imperial Tobacco on the possibility that it could acquire brands cast off in a Reynolds-Lorillard deal, but an acquisition would be a stretch financially, and the long-term benefits may be scant.", "lead_paragraph": "Investors think Imperial Tobacco has much to gain from a possible $56 billion merger of its United States peers, Reynolds American and Lorillard. The combination would require a large sale of assets to assuage antitrust regulators, and these forced sales could present bargains for Imperial.
